FAMILY MEMBER: Yes because we have brittle bones.

PATIENT: Oh, oh…

PATIENT: Chuckles
PATIENT: I would have said some words. You know.
DOCTOR: Well that was not appropriate.

DOCTOR: Yeah so if are issues along the way –
FAMILY MEMBER: They gave me this application to fill out.
DOCTOR: - let me know and we can work from this. Okay. But this was inappropriate anyway the way they confronted you like that.

FAM Sometimes people come in here and fall for that and they’re gonna give them part of their rent money and that’s what they to live. You never know.
DOCTOR: No, I agree.
FAMILY MEMBER: But what I appreciate right now is that you’re listening to us.
DOCTOR: Yeah.
FAMILY MEMBER: Because even outside of his care, you want to be treated humanely.
DOCTOR: Absolutely.

DOCTOR: I would agree. Who doesn’t need a roof over the heads first of all?
FAMILY MEMBER: There’s a halo around you that you don’t see, but we do. That’s why we’re here.
DOCTOR: Well thank you.

DOCTOR: laughs
DOCTOR: okay.

DOCTOR: If you know, for medical expenses

DOCTOR: Alright

DOCTOR: So the cancer meds do you have enough or are you gonna need a refill.

HEALTHCARE PROFESSIONAL: Yeah.

DOCTOR: Then you can eat. Okay?
PATIENT: Okay.

DOCTOR: No?

DOCTOR: Wow.

PATIENT: No.
DOCTOR: Does it help with the pain?
PATIENT: Yeah.
DOCTOR: Okay. Alright. So remember we saw that your PSA had gone up.

DOCTOR: From four to nine.

DOCTOR: So because of that, I had asked for the scans. Okay?
FAMILY MEMBER: Yeah.

FAMILY MEMBER: Um hum.
DOCTOR: Okay? The lymph nodes in your belly are getting slightly larger. So we are going to have to change your treatment and add different other treatments to this. Okay?
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: So one of the treatments is a combination of a bone medication, it’s a radiation that goes to your bones, along with the immune therapy.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay. And that’s the injection he has?
DOCTOR: Yeah.

DOCTOR: Okay.
FAMILY MEMBER: Will he need to have somebody come with him?
DOCTOR: Uh, no, but how is he going to – do you have transportation arrangements made?
FAMILY MEMBER: He drives.
DOCTOR: Oh, okay.

DOCTOR: Laughs
DOCTOR: . Okay. So then usually what I tell people-
FAMILY MEMBER: Um hum.
DOCTOR: Is for the biopsy that we will need to do –
FAMILY MEMBER: Um, hum.
DOCTOR: - for the study and on the day that he’s just starting something new-
FAMILY MEMBER: Yeah. Right.
DOCTOR: I would-
FAMILY MEMBER: You want somebody here.
DOCTOR: At least tell you that you need to be available if we need to call you.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: You know? Because any new medication to your system you might have a reaction, allergic reaction, whatever.
FAMILY MEMBER: Uh, huh.
DOCTOR: are possible side effects of these medications.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: But those are things that you cannot just sit at home and wait until your next appointment and you elicit-

DOCTOR: I know.

DOCTOR: FAM & talking at the same time
DOCTOR: That’s what I was just going to tell you that I’m going to have to lean on you a little bit more.

DOCTOR: Because you have the training already.

DOCTOR: Yeah.

DOCTOR: - If she needs to call me –
FAMILY MEMBER: Yes.
DOCTOR: - I would rather you over call than you know totally ignore - –

DOCTOR: - and then you get really sick by the time you show up in here.
PATIENT: Um, hum.
DOCTOR: As long as but I need your okay for that.
PATIENT: Okay.
FAMILY MEMBER: That’s fine.
DOCTOR: And if I have that, uh, if they say that, yes, we can go ahead, we’ll let you know and we’ll have them come back to do all the consenting and all of that procedure.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: If, however, they say, not right now, it’s too much, if it’s a week or two, I’m okay with waiting.
FAMILY MEMBER: Um hum.
DOCTOR: If it’s going to be a month or more, I don’t think then we should wait. We should look into other things.
FAMILY MEMBER: Try something else.
DOCTOR: Okay?
PATIENT: Okay.
DOCTOR: Makes sense?
PATIENT: Okay.
FAMILY MEMBER: We stand, we stand in agreement with you.
DOCTOR: Okay. But the good news is that you’re feeling well and the bone disease really did not get any worse.
FAMILY MEMBER: Right. That’s good.
DOCTOR: You know? You didn’t have any new areas, nothing else.
FAMILY MEMBER: That’s a blessing.
PATIENT: Okay.
DOCTOR: Yeah. Your pain and everything else overall is pretty well controlled.
PATIENT: Um, do I need any medication?
FAMILY MEMBER: No. She gave you the Promax. In a couple of weeks, you’ll need some more pain pills.
PATIENT: Oh, okay.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay?
DOCTOR: Okay. So should I give you a script today is what I’m thinking?
FAMILY MEMBER: Yeah.
DOCTOR: Because uh that way you don’t have to scramble last minute.

FAMILY MEMBER: Have to come back, yeah. Right.
DOCTOR: What is he on? The Norco, right?
FAMILY MEMBER: The Norco. He has
DOCTOR: Okay. Ten’s or?

FAMILY MEMBER: No. He’s on five. What you need to tell her now while she’s writing, do, do they take your pain completely away? The thing that bothers me is at night, he still doesn’t sleep, and you’re still in pain.
DOCTOR: So should I give you the higher dose, or do you thing?
PATIENT: Yeah. Yeah. I can manage.
FAMILY MEMBER: And if he doesn’t-

FAMILY MEMBER: Yeah.
DOCTOR: Okay? So we don’t totally uh-

DOCTOR: Uh huh.
FAMILY MEMBER: Even if he’s uncomfortable, he’s not irritable and tired –
DOCTOR: Yeah.
FAMILY MEMBER: But the lack of rest contributes to a lot of issues for both of us.
DOCTOR: Um hum. Sure. Yeah. That will help with uh you feeling better during the day, too.
FAMILY MEMBER: Yes.

PATIENT: Okay.
DOCTOR: Okay?
PATIENT: Okay.
DOCTOR: Alright. I’ll be back.
PATIENT: Thank you.
PATIENT: No I haven’t.

PATIENT: Okay.
DOCTOR: And we may do um your paperwork here - an appointment for six months, just kind of like a safety appointment.
PATIENT: Uh huh.
DOCTOR: But we’ll be talking to you within the next few days and seeing if we have to alter the plans at all.
PATIENT: Okay.
DOCTOR: Okay?

DOCTOR: You know you have a toddler you don't want to-

DOCTOR: - and they just get into it.
FAMILY MEMBER 1: Can he still baby sit for A___ when he’s on this medicine? Because we do split shifts.

DOCTOR: So yeah, so that that's a little bit of the hard part. Not so much for you to her, but for her to you. Because if they're their little ones are germy they're just one giant viral bacterial fest, because that's what they they do and they pick up everything. You would be a bit compromised from that.
FAMILY MEMBER 1: Could he wear a mask if he wanted?
DOCTOR: He could but just it's challenging to do that because you're kind of have the baby right here. You’re hugging her.
PATIENT: Uh I don’t think

DOCTOR: No, she can't get sick from him.

FAMILY MEMBER 2: He can kiss her.
PATIENT: Uh I try not to do that.
FAMILY MEMBER 1: Yeah. What about using their toilet? See what I’m saying, while he’s there.

Okay, but myself the one that you come in the door, I can't keep climbing the stairs and using the bathroom. Right? And that he has to discipline he still has to disinfect, right? Yeah.

PATIENT: Sometimes it’s, it’s pain, but a lot of the areas that I wasn’t haven’t pain in, uh, not much anymore. My heel on my left side was having a lot of pain that I think I had shared, and, uh, I still have some if I go and overdo it, but other than that, no, my shoulders every now and then. My biggest challenge now is, is getting a good night’s sleep.
DOCTOR: Okay.

PATIENT: And that’s because I’ve tried a number of different ways on how to sleep in the bed. I, I have these pillows that I prop up with a long pillow there, to try to lean up against the back of it so, I, you know, my back is up against the pillow. It works some nights. Some nights it doesn’t work.
DOCTOR: Okay. And so you’re having trouble falling asleep or is it that you fall asleep and then you, you’re waking up with-?
PATIENT: Well, I wake back up. And sometimes if, uh, you know how you try to get in a comfortable position? It’s trying to find that comfortable position for that night.
DOCTOR: So you’re waking up because of pain?
PATIENT: Uh, not pain all the time. Sometimes it’s just, uh, what’s the term I’m looking for?
DOCTOR: Discomfort?

PATIENT: Yeah. You know? And, uh, just trying to get in a place where you feel like this is where I need to be at, I’m happy here. So, uh, uh, one of the best sleeping place, and I hate to say it, is my living room downstairs on the couch. I prop the pillows up, and, uh, and got my favorite space, so when I lay down and put my back up right up against the back of it, but I don’t want to be in the business of sleeping on my living room couch every night, either. We have a sleep number bed that we purchased just for this, but, uh, uh, I wouldn’t recommend sleep number being if that’s what you’re going, you’re going to use it for, because it’s not all it’s, it’s cut out to be. You’re paying a lot of money for a bed. And sometimes it works, sometimes it don’t. So my biggest challenge each night is to figure out, okay, what’s going to work tonight? Is my Lazy Boy going to work? Uh, I even tried the floor with my granddaughter’s, uh, what do you call those things she has?
FAMILY MEMBER: The bean bag.
PATIENT: Uh.
DOCTOR: Looking at this list.
PATIENT: Well, my son did that. You know? He’s military.
DOCTOR: Okay.

PATIENT: So he, but actually, the oxycodone are the ones with the numbers there? One or two at the beginning. Because that’s the way he did it. And when I do it, I just put down when I’m taking it. I don’t that, take it that often. I know that, uh, uh, when I got the prescription, they told me to stay in front of the, the pain, so, or else you’re going to have to start from scratch again to get back where you were at. But I was a little leery of taking, uh, uh, uh, drugs that often.
DOCTOR: So it looks like some days you’re taking it twice, like August eighteenth?
PATIENT: Um hum.
DOCTOR: And then some days, like August twentieth, you didn’t take it at all?
PATIENT: No.
DOCTOR: And twenty-first, you didn’t take it at all, and then the twenty-second, which is today, you took one in the morning?
PATIENT: Um hum.
DOCTOR: Unless the pain is clearly getting worse, and if I feel that we have like a window of opportunity, where, you know, maybe the
DOCTOR: hasn’t worked but your cancer is not bad enough that you need chemotherapy right this second, then that might be like an opportunity to try a second trial.
PATIENT: Um hum.

DOCTOR: But if I truly believe that this pain is escalating or you’re having, you know, more bad days than good days, or, you know, you’re really not able to sleep for more than like an hour at a time because you’re waking up because of back pain, those types of things would certainly lead me towards maybe chemotherapy as the next step, and perhaps reserving that clinical trial for after the chemotherapy is over.
PATIENT: Um hum.
DOCTOR: Because that also would be a possibility, i.e., come off the
DOCTOR: trial, do some chemotherapy with the K___ oncologist, and then on the back end, when the chemotherapy is over, come back and do a different clinical trial at that point.

PATIENT: Um hum. Okay. Okay. Okay. And, again, that’s one of the reasons why I wanted to come here, uh, uh, from the um perspective of the options. And, uh, and I, I, maybe I shouldn’t say this because your recorder is here, but I do like, not only

PATIENT: the professionalism here, but, I, I like the sense of, uh, caring that the personnel here, uh, express. That’s from everybody within the building when you, when you come in. But the other thing is, when I come here to get lab work done, uh, I only get stuck one time. You know? I don’t like to be a big pincushion and you’ve gotten stuck four or five times, and the person still hasn’t hit the vein. Can I try your other arm? And I’m thinking like, come on, now.
